IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Center for Yoga, Service, and Community Since its inception in 1998, this urban ashram's mission has been one of education, service, and healing. Kashi Atlanta fulfills its mission through yoga, service, and loving spiritual community.
IRS990.MissionDesc: Center for Yoga, Service, and Community Since its inception in 1998, this urban ashram's mission has been one of education, service, and healing. Kashi Atlanta fulfills its mission through yoga, service, and loving spiritual community.
IRS990.Desc: Kashi Street Meals provides around 20,000 meals annually to the homeless; Kashi Care Team offers assistance to the terminally ill; Kashi KidsArt provides activities to hospitalized children; collects supplies for non-profit service organizations; numerous other forms of public service

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: Ongoing classes are provided to educate according to yogic principles of health and healing, meditation, spirituality, compassion, and universal consciousness, including Immune Yoga Class for those with suppressed immunity; worship services and many religious activities are conducted daily on the Organization's premises and in its temples

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: To allow the Organization to earn above-market interest income and
manage its monthly rental rate, the Organization loaned funds to an
entity owned by officers/directors. By placing the funds in a bank
certificate of deposit, the entity both pays the interest income earned
to the Organization and charges below , or equal to, market rental rates on the property
leased by the Organization. The certificates of deposit allowed the
landlord to lower its mortgage rate, which allowed the Organization to
receive below market rental rates. When the certificate of deposit
matures, the funds will be returned to the Organization. As a result of
the transactions, the Organization was able to earn a larger return on
its funds rather than if it simply placed the funds into its own
certificate of deposit.
To further the ashram (church) community, the Organization loaned funds to
an entity owned by >35% of officers/directors to renovate property housing
committed members of Organization to live in community and engage deeply in
the practices of yoga, which includes selfless service. The loan is secured
a promissory note bearing interest equal to, or above, market rates.
The Organization leases a large ashram (church) property from
an entity owned by >35% of officers/directors. The entity leases the
property at a rental rate below, or equal to, fair market value. That is, the entity
purchased the property for the benefit of the Organization and charges
rental rates favorable to the Organization.
The Organization leases community and office space from an entity owned by
>35% officers/directors. The lease rates are favorable to the Organization
(at or below comparable FMV rates) at facility housing committed members of
the Organization.
The Organization leases storage and meditation space from an entity owned by
>35% officers/directors. The lease rates are favorable to the Organization
where rates are comparable to, or below, FMV rates while being located
close to the Organization's primary location.
Business relationship.
The Form 990 is reviewed by the Organization's CFO before filing.
The Organization provides documents upon request.
